thread.section_title: Travel News, Tips, and Guides - USATODAY.com
thread.title: These Caribbean all-inclusive resorts have the biggest bang for your buck
thread.title_full: These Caribbean all-inclusive resorts have the biggest bang for your buck

title: These Caribbean all-inclusive resorts have the biggest bang for your buck
text:
Just 90 minutes east of the Sangster International Airport in Montego Bay, Beaches Ocho Rios entertains kids (and their parents) with the extraordinary (and free) opportunity to participate in the Hawksbill Turtle Watching Program. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen Courtesy of the eco-astute Sandals Foundation; the philanthropic arm of Sandals Resorts International, kids get the rare chance to see the turtles nesting along the resort’s shoreline. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen “Sea turtles are on the endangered list of species”, explains Jonathan Hernould, environmental officer. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen “Bringing awareness of these incredible creatures and their journey from egg back to the sea is an experience the lucky families who witness this miraculous moment will never forget.” Sandals Resorts Fullscreen Eco-cool kids enrolled in the turtle program learn how to protect the nests from poachers and high tides. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen They'll also learn how turtle experts predict when the baby turtles will be born and then make their way back into the sea (generally in the early evening between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m.). Turtle season typically runs from May to December. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen On the blissfully un-touristy south coast of Jamaica in a small fishing village (4,000 residents) called White House, Sandals Whitehouse — located 40 miles from the Sangster International Airport — ups the all-inclusive ante with a host of funky free stuff for adults-only. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen Above and way beyond the standard-issue menu of amenities, every Thursday is 'Jamaican Backyard' ; a full day of rum tastings, soca and reggae lessons and classes that teach eager guests how to walk and talk like a Jamaican. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen “Our guests take on the challenge of becoming seasoned Jamaicans,” smiles Geraldine Willis, entertainment manager, “engaging in irie activities that are clearly ‘no problem’ for our staff, bartenders and chefs.” Sandals Resorts Fullscreen Partnering with Appleton Estates; the island's iconic rum brand, bartenders at the Blue Fields Beach Club conduct intimate classes for no more than 20 sippers. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen Jamaica Day kicks off with a lesson about the island's national heroes like Usian Bolt and Bob Marley and is followed by a cooking class where chefs whip up saltfish and ackee and jerk chicken and after lunch, Jamaican-wannabees learn how to speak the native Patois language. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen When the sun sets, Jamaica Day grads show off their new dance moves until the wee hours. Sandals Resorts Fullscreen Conveniently perched on the south coast of St. Lucia, Coconut Bay Beach Resort is the only all-inclusive within minutes of the Hewanorra International Airport. Coconut Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen This is a big ticket because many of the other resorts are in the north, which is a long and hilly drive from the airport. Coconut Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen Located on mile-long Anse de Sables Beach, 250-room resort with an adults-only wing called Harmony and one for families called Splash. Coconut Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen The resort also tempts with unlimited free fun at CocoLand; the island's largest water park. Coconut Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen Coco Bay Beach Resort boasts the Caribbean’s first official paintball game park that is large enough for ten players, and it's free for guests to play. Coco Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen With views of the Maria Islands Nature Reserve, the resort adds to the standard-issue all-you-can-eat and drink formula with a free Kidz Klub (for ages three to 12) that has an air conditioned playroom and super cool pirate ship. Coco Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen Gifts without a price tag like a CocoPak backpack for each kid with all sorts of fun stuff and a cell phone for parents who may want to check in on their kids in between bites of Auntie Em’s legendary French toast are a nice touch. Coco Bay Beach Resort Fullscreen Sweetening the pot, the resort's Rum Master (yes, a real job we’d all like to have) offers tasting classes at the Sugar Cane Rum Bar, also without an additional cost. Coco Bay Beach Resort and Spa Fullscreen The first all-inclusive on Cable Beach in Nassau, a vacation at Breezes Resort means more than an afternoon of snorkeling and a nightcap after dinner. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Although there are plenty of water sports and cocktails, the casual seaside resort gets creative with activities that stand out in the all-inclusive crowd. Free to guests, climbing the rock wall and trapeze classes break up a day on the beach. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen The 30-foot-high rock wall is color-coded for levels of difficulty, making it ideal for both newbies and pros. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Circus performer wannabees can learn how to fly through the air on a trapeze in classes taught Tuesday - Sunday from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Definitely not for scream queens, instructors teach the fearless how to plunge from 20 feet above the ground and how to do the bird’s nest move with you belly facing down and the tops of your feet on each rope. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Sonesta Resorts on St Maarten has a program called ‘Stay at one, play at three’ and without any fine print, it’s a deal too good to pass up. Sonesta Resorts Fullscreen A stay at the upscale adults-only Sonesta Ocean Point is a ticket to eat and play, without any additional costs, at the adjacent Sonesta Maho Beach and at Sonesta Great Bay Beach closer to the capital city of Phillipsburg. Melanie Reffes Fullscreen For those staying at either Sonesta Maho or Great Bay, you can eat and play at both resorts for the price of a stay at one of them. Melanie Reffes Fullscreen Fun and fabulous, the trio of Sonestas are the only all-inclusives on the Dutch side of the island. The trio of resorts all front terrific beaches and come with boatload of free fun in the water from swim-up pool bars to water sports galore. Sonesta Resorts Fullscreen CuisinArt Golf Resort on Anguilla, corporately related to the kitchen appliance company of the same name, is foodie heaven with an on-site hydroponic farm, stellar restaurants and the best sushi this side of Japan. CuisinArt Golf Resort Fullscreen Not a typical all-inclusive, the resort is more a hybrid variety with a five–night package called ‘Epicurean Immersion’ offered through December 18. CuisinArt Golf Resort Fullscreen A picnic basket of gourmet perks, those on the foodie plan enjoy a sumptuous breakfast daily at Café Med or in their elegant en suite, lunches and dinners for two at any of the resorts restaurants and a Chef's Tasting dinner menu. CuisinArt Golf Resort Fullscreen Raising the bar are ‘Secrets of the Chef’ classes on Fridays, wine tastings on Mondays or Tuesday and a ‘Sushi 101' class offered every Monday at Tokyo Bay, taught by Chef Jim Richardson. CuisinArt Golf Resort Fullscreen “My one-hour class covers the basics like rice steaming and sushi rolling with the added bonus of lunch prepared by my star students.” Josveek Huligar, CuisinArt Golf Resort Fullscreen Gratis tours of the hydroponic garden are fun for anyone who either has a green thumb or dreams of having one. CuisinArt Golf Resort Fullscreen Forget paying extra for babysitters at the 342-room Sunscape Curacao Resort. Sunscape Curacao Resort Fullscreen For kids aged three to 12, Explorers Club is open from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. with free activities like sack races, sandcastle building competitions and (with a green light from mom and dad); a campout adventure. Sunscape Curacao Resort Fullscreen For finicky tweens and teens 13 to 17 years old, Core Zone opens at 9 a.m. and stays open until 11 p.m. Sunscape Curacao Resort Fullscreen Core Zone offers tweens and teens pool tables, big screen TV, horseshoe games, bocce ball, PlayStation 3, karaoke and movies. Sunscape Beach Resort Fullscreen The beachfront all-inclusive is entertainment-central with four pools including one for kids, all-you-can-play water sports, 24-hour food choices and six bars including the Manatee swim-up with last call at 11 p.m. Sunscape Curacao Resort Fullscreen Located just 30 minutes from the Punta Cana International Airport, Royalton Punta Cana Resort is a star on Bavaro Beach in the Dominican Republic. Adiseshan Shankar, Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Upscale and elegant, the sprawling resort tempts wallet-watchers with a two-for-one- deal that means (free) access to Memories Splash Punta Cana with its gigantic Water Park and disco. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen For savvy guests looking to max out their all-inclusive vacay, ask about the lively roster of poolside workshops. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Roll with the best in an informative cigar rolling class, where professional cigar rollers teach the tricks of the trade. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen A closeup of the tools used during a cigar rolling class at Royalton Punta Cana Resort Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen For couples aiming to get their groove on, the Mamajuana workshop is the place to be to learn how to mix the local aphrodisiac made from tree bark, herbs, honey-soaked rum and red wine. Blue Diamond Resorts Fullscreen Even at an all-inclusive, a scenic sail on a comfy catamaran can cost a few extra bucks, as can a scuba lesson or a relaxing ride in a glass bottom boat. Not so at Mango Bay Resort on Barbados. Mango Bay Resort Fullscreen Close to fashionable Holetown on the west coast, 76-room Mango Bay Resort ratchets up the free activities list with Hawksbill turtle spotting. Mango Bay Resort Fullscreen You can search for the reptiles on a catamaran from 9:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays. Mango Bay Resort Fullscreen Mango Bay Resort offers free scuba lessons Tuesdays and Fridays for adults and kids over 8 years old. Mango Bay Resort Fullscreen For those who prefer not to get their hair wet; complimentary cruises aboard a glass bottom boat gets going every Friday. Mango Bay Resort Fullscreen On the high-rise strip fronting Aruba's Palm Beach, 205-room Divi Aruba Resort steps up to the plate with an all-inclusive menu that goes beyond the buffet and the beach. Divi Resorts Fullscreen There’s a complimentary ‘Learn to Windsurf’ clinic, snorkeling classes in the pool, guided biking tours, synchronized swimming shows, game-winning tips offered by the pros in the casino and classes in the local language called Papiamento. diviaruba.com Fullscreen Skip the pricey entertainment on the strip and keep your cash in your pocket with a front row seat at any one of the pulsating shows. arubadivi.com Fullscreen Try limbo lessons, tapping your toes to the beat of the island’s only steel drum band, getting groovy at Cuban dance performances and reggae concerts and when the sun sets, snag a ringside seat for a spectacular fireworks show. diviaruba.com Fullscreen For more variety, Divi guests can explore the next door Tamarijn Aruba Resort at no additional cost with its nine restaurants, seven bars and three freshwater pools. Aruba Divi Resorts Fullscreen Like this topic? You may also like these photo galleries: Replay Autoplay Show Thumbnails Show Captions Last Slide Next Slide “Sea turtles are on the endangered list of species”, explains Jonathan Hernould, environmental officer. (Photo: Sandals Resorts)
970 CONNECT 219 TWEET 14 LINKEDIN 21 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Getting something (or a lot of things) for nothing is a big draw while on vacation. Unlimited food, hooch and fun in the sun is the hallmark of an all-inclusive resort and although you can have a vacay of a lifetime not paying for anything once you check-in, you can have even more fun sniffing out the creative extras that come without an additional price tag. Check out our 10 top picks that rev up the all-inclusive meter with complimentary add-ons like trapeze lessons and catamaran sails to turtle watching programs for kids and cigar-rolling classes for grown-ups.
Beaches Ocho Rios | Jamaica
Royalty among all-inclusives, Sandals Resorts for adults and family-friendly Beaches (the two properties have the same owners) know how to do it right. Wildly popular for the unlimited eat and drink idea, the resorts also offer a host of other freebies to guests who know how to hunt them down. Just 90 minutes east of the Sangster International Airport in Montego Bay, Beaches Ocho Rios entertains kids (and their parents) with the extraordinary (and free) opportunity to participate in the Hawksbill Turtle Watching Program. Courtesy of the eco-astute Sandals Foundation; the philanthropic arm of Sandals Resorts International, kids get the rare chance to see the turtles nesting along the resort’s shoreline. “Sea turtles are on the endangered list of species”, explains Jonathan Hernould, environmental officer, “bringing awareness of these incredible creatures and their journey from egg back to the sea is an experience the lucky families who witness this miraculous moment will never forget.” Eco-cool kids enrolled in the turtle program learn how to protect the nests from poachers and high tides and how turtle experts predict when the baby turtles will be born and then make their way back into the sea (generally in the early evening between 4:30 p.m. and 6 p.m.). Turtle season typically runs from May to December.
Sandals Whitehouse | Jamaica
Jamaica Day kicks off with a lesson about the island's national heroes like Usian Bolt and Bob Marley and is followed by a cooking class where chefs whip up saltfish and ackee and jerk chicken and after lunch, Jamaican-wannabees learn how to speak the native Patois language. (Photo: Sandals Resorts)
On the blissfully un-touristy south coast of Jamaica in a small fishing village (4,000 residents) called White House, Sandals Whitehouse — located 40 miles from the Sangster International Airport — ups the all-inclusive ante with a host of funky free stuff for adults-only. Above and way beyond the standard-issue menu of amenities, every Thursday is 'Jamaican Backyard' ; a full day of rum tastings, soca and reggae lessons and classes that teach eager guests how to walk and talk like a Jamaican. “Our guests take on the challenge of becoming seasoned Jamaicans,” smiles Geraldine Willis, entertainment manager, “engaging in irie activities that are clearly ‘no problem’ for our staff, bartenders and chefs.” Partnering with Appleton Estates; the island's iconic rum brand, bartenders at the Blue Fields Beach Club conduct intimate classes for no more than 20 sippers. “We are a family business that is passionately committed to our country of Jamaica,” said Adam Stewart, CEO of Sandals Resorts International, "it's great to see two local brands joining together to offer a true Caribbean experience.” Jamaica Day kicks off with a lesson about the island's national heroes like Usian Bolt and Bob Marley and is followed by a cooking class where chefs whip up saltfish and ackee and jerk chicken and after lunch, Jamaican-wannabees learn how to speak the native Patois language. When the sun sets, Jamaica Day grads show off their new dance moves until the wee hours.
Coconut Bay Beach Resort | St Lucia
Sweetening the pot, the resort's Rum Master (yes, a real job we’d all like to have) offers tasting classes at the Sugar Cane Rum Bar, also without an additional cost. (Photo: Coco Bay Beach Resort and Spa)
Conveniently perched on the south coast of St. Lucia, Coconut Bay Beach Resort is the only all-inclusive within minutes of the Hewanorra International Airport. This is a big ticket because many of the other resorts are in the north, which is a long and hilly drive from the airport. Located on mile-long Anse de Sables Beach, 250-room resort with an adults-only wing called Harmony and one for families called Splash also tempts with unlimited free fun at CocoLand; the island's largest water park and the Caribbean’s first official paintball game park that is large enough for ten players. With views of the Maria Islands Nature Reserve, the resort adds to the standard-issue all-you-can-eat and drink formula with a free Kidz Klub (for ages three to 12) that has an air conditioned playroom and super cool pirate ship. Gifts without a price tag like a CocoPak backpack for each kid with all sorts of fun stuff and a cell phone for parents who may want to check in on their kids in between bites of Auntie Em’s legendary French toast are a nice touch. Sweetening the pot, the resort's Rum Master (yes, a real job we’d all like to have) offers tasting classes at the Sugar Cane Rum Bar, also without an additional cost.
Breezes Resort | The Bahamas
Definitely not for scream queens, instructors teach the fearless how to plunge from 20 feet above the ground and how to do the bird’s nest move with you belly facing down and the tops of your feet on each rope. (Photo: Blue Diamond Resorts)
The first all-inclusive on Cable Beach in Nassau, a vacation at Breezes Resort means more than an afternoon of snorkeling and a nightcap after dinner. Although there are plenty of water sports and cocktails, the casual seaside resort gets creative with activities that stand out in the all-inclusive crowd. Free to guests, climbing the rock wall and trapeze classes break up a day on the beach. The 30-foot-high rock wall is color-coded for levels of difficulty, making it ideal for both newbies and pros. Circus performer wannabees can learn how to fly through the air on a trapeze in classes taught Tuesday - Sunday from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m. Definitely not for scream queens, instructors teach the fearless how to plunge from 20 feet above the ground and how to do the bird’s nest move with you belly facing down and the tops of your feet on each rope. For those who prefer their fun with their two feet firmly on the ground, tennis instructors give free lessons on courts lit for night play, bartenders are popular for their gratis mixology classes and for those wanting to brush up on their windsurfing techniques; instruction is on the house. If you happen to fall in love while hanging upside down on the trapeze or inching your way up the rock wall, weddings at the resort are free with a minimum stay.
Sonesta Resorts | St. Maarten
A stay at the upscale adults-only Sonesta Ocean Point is a ticket to eat and play, without any additional costs, at the adjacent Sonesta Maho Beach and at Sonesta Great Bay Beach closer to the capital city of Phillipsburg. (Photo: Melanie Reffes)
It’s called ‘Stay at one, play at three’ and without any fine print, it’s a deal too good to pass up. A stay at the upscale adults-only Sonesta Ocean Point is a ticket to eat and play, without any additional costs, at the adjacent Sonesta Maho Beach and at Sonesta Great Bay Beach closer to the capital city of Phillipsburg. For those staying at either Sonesta Maho or Great Bay, you can eat and play at both resorts for the price of a stay at one of them. Fun and fabulous, the trio of Sonestas are the only all-inclusives on the Dutch side of the island. For the party hearty, both Maho resorts are across the street from the Casino Royale; the largest on the island and the Tantra Nightclub; also the largest on the island. The trio of resorts all front terrific beaches and come with boatload of free fun in the water from swim-up pool bars to water sports galore.
CuisinArt Golf Resort | Anguilla
Raising the bar are ‘Secrets of the Chef’ classes on Fridays, wine tastings on Mondays or Tuesday and a ‘Sushi 101' class offered every Monday at Tokyo Bay, taught by Chef Jim Richardson. (Photo: CuisinArt Golf Resort)
Stunning in blue and white and inspired by the Greek island of Mykonos, CuisinArt Golf Resort , corporately related to the kitchen appliance company of the same name, is foodie heaven with an on-site hydroponic farm, stellar restaurants and the best sushi this side of Japan. Not a typical all-inclusive, the resort is more a hybrid variety with a five–night package called ‘Epicurean Immersion’ offered through December 18. A picnic basket of gourmet perks, those on the foodie plan enjoy a sumptuous breakfast daily at Café Med or in their elegant en suite, lunches and dinners for two at any of the resorts restaurants and a Chef's Tasting dinner menu. Raising the bar are ‘Secrets of the Chef’ classes on Fridays, wine tastings on Mondays or Tuesday and a ‘Sushi 101' class offered every Monday at Tokyo Bay, taught by Chef Joe Richardson. “My one-hour class covers the basics like rice steaming and sushi rolling with the added bonus of lunch prepared by my star students.” Gratis tours of the hydroponic garden are fun for anyone who either has a green thumb or dreams of having one.
Sunscape Curacao Resort | Curacao
Forget paying extra for babysitters at the 342-room Sunscape Curacao Resort. (Photo: Sunscape Curacao Resort)
Forget paying extra for babysitters at the 342-room Sunscape Curacao Resort . For kids aged three to 12, Explorers Club is open from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. with free activities like sack races, sandcastle building competitions and (with a green light from mom and dad); a campout adventure. For finicky tweens and teens 13 to 17 years old, Core Zone opens at 9 a.m. and stays open until 11 p.m. with pool tables, big screen TV, horseshoe games, bocce ball, PlayStation 3, karaoke and movies. The beachfront all-inclusive is entertainment-central with four pools including one for kids, all-you-can-play water sports, 24-hour food choices and six bars including the Manatee swim-up with last call at 11 p.m. Grown-up free fun includes shopping and sightseeing shuttles to the capital city of Willemstad; two miles from the resort, nighttime play at Princess Casino and relaxing rubs and wraps in the Spa.
Royalton Punta Cana Resort | Dominican Republic
Roll with the best in an informative cigar rolling class, where professional cigar rollers teach the tricks of the trade. (Photo: Blue Diamond Resorts)
Located just 30 minutes from the Punta Cana International Airport, Royalton Punta Cana Resort is a star on Bavaro Beach. Upscale and elegant, the sprawling resort tempts wallet-watchers with a two-for-one- deal that means (free) access to Memories Splash Punta Cana with its gigantic Water Park and disco. A cut above many of the other seaside all-inclusives, the 470-room Royalton welcomes families with 10 restaurants, nine bars, a large casino and high-tech conveniences like free Wi-Fi and USB recharging stations. For a few extra well-spent dollars, membership in the Diamond Club comes with a butler, private pool, fast check-in and a creative pillow menu. For savvy guests looking to max out their all-inclusive vacay, ask about the lively roster of poolside workshops. Roll with the best in an informative cigar rolling class, where professional cigar rollers teach the tricks of the trade. For couples aiming to get their groove on (or their groove back), the Mamajuana workshop is the place to be to learn how to mix the local aphrodisiac made from tree bark, herbs, honey-soaked rum and red wine.
Mango Bay Resort | Barbados
Close to fashionable Holetown on the west coast, 76-room Mango Bay Resort ratchets up the free activities list with Hawksbill turtle spotting. (Photo: Mango Bay Resort)
Even at an all-inclusive, a scenic sail on a comfy catamaran can cost a few extra bucks, as can a scuba lesson or a relaxing ride in a glass bottom boat. Not so at this all-inclusive. Close to fashionable Holetown on the west coast, 76-room Mango Bay Resort ratchets up the free activities list with Hawksbill turtle spotting on a catamaran from 9:30 a.m. to 11:30 a.m. Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays, scuba lessons Tuesdays and Fridays for adults and kids over 8 years old and for those who prefer not to get their hair wet; complimentary cruises aboard a glass bottom boat gets going every Friday.
Divi Aruba Resort | Aruba
There’s a complimentary ‘Learn to Windsurf’ clinic, snorkeling classes in the pool, guided biking tours, synchronized swimming shows, game-winning tips offered by the pros in the casino and classes in the local language called Papiamento. (Photo: diviaruba.com)
On the high-rise strip fronting Palm Beach, 205-room Divi Aruba Resort steps up to the plate with an all-inclusive menu that goes beyond the buffet and the beach. There’s a complimentary ‘Learn to Windsurf’ clinic, snorkeling classes in the pool, guided biking tours, synchronized swimming shows, game-winning tips offered by the pros in the casino and classes in the local language called Papiamento. Skip the pricey entertainment on the strip and keep your cash in your pocket with a front row seat at any one of the pulsating shows. Try limbo lessons, tapping your toes to the beat of the island’s only steel drum band, getting groovy at Cuban dance performances and reggae concerts and when the sun sets, snag a ringside seat for a spectacular fireworks show. For more variety, Divi guests can explore the next door Tamarijn Aruba Resort at no additional cost with its nine restaurants, seven bars and three freshwater pools.
